BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the sometimes moderate wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on wind-loaded slopes. In particular on very steep slopes small to medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.
The soft wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Saturday the wind has been moderate to strong. In gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the wind slabs have increased in size. They can be released by a single winter sport participant.
Fresh snow and large quantities of wind-drifted snow of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence. More dry avalanches are possible, but they can be large.
Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day after a long period of poor weather.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. They are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow-covered wind slabs of last week remain in some cases prone to triggering in particular on north to east to southwest facing aspects above approximately 2000 m. They can be released by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack here.
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from southeasterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. Fresh wind slabs can be released easily.
Especially in extremely steep terrain dry loose snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be light to moderate over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above the tree line.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind has transported the new snow significantly. New snow and wind slabs are lying mostly on an icy crust. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
In many places there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be light to moderate over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above approximately 1400 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind has transported the new snow significantly. New snow and wind slabs are lying mostly on an icy crust. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be light to moderate over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above approximately 1500 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.
Below approximately 1400 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind. These can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases or triggered naturally.
The wind slabs have formed adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects and generally at elevated altitudes. They are to be bypassed in particular in very steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In the last few days large surface-area wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist small and medium sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow has fallen since Friday. Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry avalanches are possible. The wind slabs are mostly shallow but can be released in isolated cases.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. These avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 1000 m snow has fallen since Friday over a wide area.
Only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind, easily released wind slabs formed in the last few days above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line, in the regions exposed to a lot of wind especially. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

As a consequence of solar radiation only isolated dry loose snow avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The new snow is lying on surface hoar in some places in areas close to the tree line. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind, easily released wind slabs formed in the last few days above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line, in the regions exposed to a lot of wind especially. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. In high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are present in all aspects.

As a consequence of solar radiation only isolated dry loose snow avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The new snow is lying on surface hoar in some places in areas close to the tree line. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In the last few days large surface-area wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist small and medium sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from southeasterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. They will be deposited on soft layers on west to north to northeast facing aspects. Fresh wind slabs can be released easily.
In addition the old wind slabs are prone to triggering in some cases still. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, especially on very steep slopes. They are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The conditions are mostly favourable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 5 to 10 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1200 m. The weather conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the snowpack. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.
